descriptions.content:
Abbreviations are very common in Literary Tibetan. They are of two kinds: phonic and graphic. The former usually occur only in the case of quadrisyllabic expressions, and consist of omitting the second and fourth syllables.

  • བྱང་སེམས་ = བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་ “Bodhisattva”
  • དེ་གཤེགས་ = དེ་བཞིན་གཤེགས་པ་ “Tathāgata”
  • ཐེག་ཆེན་ = ཐེག་པ་ཆེན་པོ་ “Mahāyāna”
  • ཕྱག་རྡོར་ = ཕྱག་ན་རྡོ་རྗེ་ “The bodhisattva Vajrapāṇi (or Chakna Dorjé)”
  • དགེ་སློབ་ = དགེ་རྒན་དང་སློབ་མ་ “Master and disciple(s)”
  • ཞིང་འབྲོག་ = ཞིང་པ་དང་འབྲོག་པ་ “Farmers and nomads”

The same principle applies in the spoken language for abridging personal names of four syllables:

  • ཚེ་རྡོར་ Tsedor = ཚེ་རིང་རྡོ་རྗེ་ Tsering Dorjé
  • བཀྲ་དཔལ་ Trapel = བཀྲ་ཤིས་དཔལ་ལྡན་ Trashi Penden
  • ཆོས་རྒྱམ་ Chögyam = ཆོས་ཀྱི་རྒྱ་མཚོ་ Chökyi Gyatso (or Gyamtso)
  • བསོད་སྒྲོན་ Södrön = བསོད་ནམས་སྒྲོལ་མ་ Sönam Drölma

Note that in some cases, a resyllabification occurs whereby the prefixed or the superscribed letter of the following syllable is interpreted as the final of the preceding syllable. The written orthography records this phenomenon. For example, the last letter in Chögyam or Tsedor belongs in fact to the fourth syllable (that has been omitted), respectively མཚོ་ and རྗེ་.

Graphic abbreviations consist of using special signs to replace a group of letters. The following are the most common:

The circle ༚, written above a letter, replaces the suffix མ:

  • ལཾ་ = ལམ་

The ཊ་ (reversed ཏ་) substitutes for the suffix གས་:

  • ལཊ་ = ལགས་
  • ལེཊ་ = ལེགས་

There are also abbreviations in which two syllables are graphically compacted into a single syllable:

  • བོུ་ = བུ་མོ་ “Girl”
  • ཚོུ་ = ཆུ་ཚོད་ “Hour”
  • བཀྲིས་བདེ་ལེཊ་ = བཀྲ་ཤིས་བདེ་ལེགས་
